### 1. Piece-wise linear mixed-effects models
First, without covariates, we consider some simple piece-wise linear mixed-effects models of post-infection CD4 as a function of time since HIV-infection. Suppose that we pick two interior knots at t = 2, 4 years after HIV infection. Give your ï¬nal chosen model, and estimates and 95% CIâ€™s for the ï¬xed effects under the following three scenarios. 

$$ Y_{ij} = Î²X_{ij} +b_iZ_{ij} +\epsilon_{ij}$$

$Y_{ij}$: Post-infection CD4
Î²: The ï¬xed effect
$b_i$: The random effect for subject i. 
$X_{ij},Z_{ij}$: Covariate matrices for subject i. 
$\epsilon_{ij}$ âˆ¼ N(0,Ïƒ2) is the measurement error.

### 1.1 local constant ï¬t
Using the basis functions B1(t) = 1[t<2], B2(t) = 1[2â‰¤t<4] and B3(t) = 1[4â‰¤t], with random-eï¬€ects for each of the basis functions; 

Model:
$$ Y_{ij} =(Î²_1 +b_{1i})B_1(t_{ij})+(Î²_2 +b_{2i})B_2(t_{ij})+(Î²_3 +b_{3i})B_3(t_{ij})+\epsilon_{ij} $$ 

```{r}
time=BMACS$Time
B1<-function(t) I(t<2)
B1=as.numeric(B1(time))
B2<-function(t) I((t<4)& (t>=2))
B2=as.numeric(B2(time))
B3<-function(t) I(t>=4)
B3=as.numeric(B3(time))
B4<-function(t) t*I(t<2)
B4=as.numeric(B4(time))
B5<-function(t) t*I((t<4)& (t>=2))
B5=as.numeric(B5(time))
B6<-function(t) t*I(t>=4)
B6=as.numeric(B6(time))
b1=1
b2=function(t) return(t)
b2=as.numeric(b2(time))
b3=function(t) return(ifelse(t>2, t-2, 0))
b3=as.numeric(b3(time))
b4=function(t) return(ifelse(t>4, t-4, 0))
b4=as.numeric(b4(time))

data1<-cbind(BMACS, B1,B2,B3, B4,B5,B6,b1,b2,b3,b4)
model.1.1<-lmer(CD4~ B1+B2+B3 -1 +(B1+B2+B3 -1 |ID), data= data1)
summary(model.1.1)

```

Use Bootstrap to compute 95% confidence interval.

```{r}
set.seed(1) 
unique.ID=unique(BMACS$ID) 
nID=length(unique.ID) 
bootsample=function(){ 
  resample.ID=sample(unique.ID,nID,replace=T) 
  do.call("rbind",lapply(1:nID,function(i) subset(BMACS,ID==resample.ID[i]))) 
  } 
bootstrap.1.1=sapply(1:200,function(o){ 
  b=bootsample() 
  t=b$Time 
  B1<-function(t) I(t<2) 
  B1=as.numeric(B1(t)) 
  B2<-function(t) I((t<4)& (t>=2)) 
  B2=as.numeric(B2(t)) 
  B3<-function(t) I(t>=4) 
  B3=as.numeric(B3(t))
  b<-cbind(b, B1,B2,B3) 
  boot.1.1<-lmer(CD4~ B1+B2+B3 -1 +(B1+B2+B3 -1 |ID), data= b) 
  return(fixef(boot.1.1))
  }) 


bootstrap.1.1=as.matrix(bootstrap.1.1) 
upper95=apply(bootstrap.1.1,1,quantile,0.975) 
lower95=apply(bootstrap.1.1,1,quantile,0.025) 
estimate=fixef(model.1.1)
cbind(estimate,lower95,upper95)

```


### 1.2 local linear ï¬t without assuming continuity at the knots.

Three separate straight lines at t < 2, 2 â‰¤ t < 4 and 4 â‰¤ t, with random-effects for the intercepts only.

Model:
$$ Y_{ij} =(Î²_1 +b_{1i})B_1(t_{ij})+(Î²_2 +b_{2i})B_2(t_{ij})+(Î²_3 +b_{3i})B_3(t_{ij})+Î²_4B_4(t_{ij})+Î²_5B_5(t_{ij})+Î²_6B_6(t_{ij})+\epsilon_{ij} $$ 

The model fit 3 lines with own intercept and slop, and the knots are not forced to beconnected. Only the intercept terms have random eï¬€ect.

```{r}
model.1.2<-lmer(CD4~ B1+B2+B3 -1 +B4 + B5 + B6 +(B1+B2+B3 -1 |ID), data= data1)
summary(model.1.2)

set.seed(1)
bootstrap.1.2=sapply(1:200,function(o){
  b=bootsample()
  t=b$Time
  B1<-function(t) I(t<2)
  B1=as.numeric(B1(t))
  B2<-function(t) I((t<4)& (t>=2))
  B2=as.numeric(B2(t))
  B3<-function(t) I(t>=4)
  B3=as.numeric(B3(t))
  B4<-function(t) t*I(t<2)
  B4=as.numeric(B4(t))
  B5<-function(t) t*I((t<4)& (t>=2))
  B5=as.numeric(B5(t))
  B6<-function(t) t*I(t>=4)
  B6=as.numeric(B6(t))
  b<-cbind(b, B1,B2,B3,B4,B5,B6)
  fit1.2<-lmer(CD4~ B1+B2+B3 -1 +B4 + B5 + B6 +(B1+B2+B3 -1 |ID), data= b)
  return(fixef(fit1.2))
})
bootstrap.1.2=as.matrix(bootstrap.1.2)
estimate=fixef(model.1.2)
upper95=apply(bootstrap.1.2,1,quantile,0.975)
lower95=apply(bootstrap.1.2,1,quantile,0.025)
cbind(estimate,lower95,upper95)

```


### 1.3 local linear ï¬t with continuity at the knots

Using B1(t) = 1, B2(t) = t, B3(t) = (tâˆ’2)+ and B4(t) = (tâˆ’4)+, with random-effects for each of the basis functions. 

Model:

$$ Y_{ij} =Î²_1 +b_{1i}+(Î²_2 +b_{2i})t_{ij}+(Î²_3 +b_{3i})(t_{ij}-2)^++(Î²_4+b_{4i})(t_{ij}-4)^++\epsilon_{ij} $$

```{r}
model.1.3<-lmer(CD4~b2+b3+b4+(b2+b3+b4|ID), data= data1)
summary(model.1.3)
```


```{r}
set.seed(1)
bootstrap.1.3=sapply(1:200,function(o){
  b=bootsample()
  t=b$Time
  B2=function(t) return(t)
  B2=as.numeric(B2(t))
  B3=function(t) return(ifelse(t>2, t-2, 0))
  B3=as.numeric(B3(t))
  B4=function(t) return(ifelse(t>4, t-4, 0))
  B4=as.numeric(B4(t))
  cd41.3<-cbind(b, B2,B3,B4)
  fit1.3<-lmer(CD4~B2+B3+B4+(B2+B3+B4|ID), data= b)
  return(fixef(fit1.3))
})
bootstrap.1.3=as.matrix(bootstrap.1.3)
estimate=fixef(model.1.3)
upper95=apply(bootstrap.1.3,1,quantile,0.975)
lower95=apply(bootstrap.1.3,1,quantile,0.025)
cbind(estimate,lower95,upper95)
```


### 1.4 Interpretations and clinical conclusions

What are your interpretations and clinical conclusions from the results obtained in #1.1, #1.2 and #1.3?

```{r}
anova(model.1.1,model.1.2,model.1.3,refit=F) 
```

Model.1.3 is the best model because its AIC is the smallest.

In conclusion, patients' post CD4 level decreases as time passes by since infection. The decreasing speed is the fastest in the ï¬rst two years after infection, becomes slower in the 2nd-4th year, and even slower after the 4th year.


### 2. Extend the analysis in #1 by including smoking status as the covariate. 
In this case, you will consider the varying-coeffcient mixed-eï¬€ects models of the form

$$ Y_{ij} =Î²_0(t) +b_{0i}(t)+Î²_1(t)X_i(t)+b_{1i}(t)X_i(t)+\epsilon_t$$
where Xi(t) is the smoking status, b0i(t) and b1i(t) are subject-speciï¬c deviation curves and $\epsilon_t$ is the independent measurement error. 

Give your ï¬nal chosen model, and estimates and 95% CIâ€™s for the ï¬xed eï¬€ects under the following three scenarios:

### 2.1 Local constant ï¬t
Local constant ï¬t using the basis functions in #1.1 for Î²0(t), b0i(t), Î²1(t) and b1i(t); 

Model:
$$ Y_{ij} =(Î²_1+b_{1i})B_1t_{ij}+(Î²_2 +b_{2i})B_2t_{ij}+(Î²_3 +b_{3i})B_3t_{ij}+Î²_4B_1t_{ij}S_{ij}+Î²_5B_2t_{ij}S_{ij}+Î²_6B_3t_{ij}S_{ij}+\epsilon_{ij} $$

#yij =Î²1B1(tij)+Î²2B2(tij)+Î²3B3(tij)+ (Î²4 +b4i)B1(tij)Sij +(Î²5 +b5i)B2(tij)Sij +(Î²6 +b6i)B3(tij)Sij +ij (2.1.2)
#yij =(Î²1 +b1i)B1(tij)+(Î²2 +b2i)B2(tij)+(Î²3 +b3i)B3(tij)+ (Î²4 +b4i)B1(tij)Sij +(Î²5 +b5i)B2(tij)Sij +(Î²6 +b6i)B3(tij)Sij +ij 

```{r}
smoke=BMACS$Smoke
S1=B1*smoke
S2=B2*smoke
S3=B3*smoke
S4=B4*smoke
S5=B5*smoke
S6=B6*smoke
s1=b1*smoke
s2=b2*smoke
s3=b3*smoke
s4=b4*smoke

data2=cbind(data1,S1,S2,S3,S4,S5,S6,s1,s2,s3,s4)
model.2.1<-lmer(CD4~-1+B1+B2+B3+S1+S2+S3+(-1+B1+B2+B3|ID), data= data2)
summary(model.2.1)
```

Bootstrap

```{r}
set.seed(1)
bootstrap.2.1=sapply(1:200,function(o){
  b=bootsample()
  t=b$Time
  s=b$Smoke
  B1<-function(t) I(t<2)
  B1=as.numeric(B1(t))
  B2<-function(t) I((t<4)& (t>=2))
  B2=as.numeric(B2(t))
  B3<-function(t) I(t>=4)
  B3=as.numeric(B3(t))
  S1=B1*s
  S2=B2*s
  S3=B3*s
  cd42.1<-cbind(b, B1,B2,B3,S1,S2,S3)
  fit2.1<-lmer(CD4~-1+B1+B2+B3+S1+S2+S3+(-1+B1+B2+B3|ID), data= b)
  return(fixef(fit2.1))
})
bootstrap.2.1=as.matrix(bootstrap.2.1)
estimate=fixef(model.2.1)
upper95=apply(bootstrap.2.1,1,quantile,0.975)
lower95=apply(bootstrap.2.1,1,quantile,0.025)
cbind(estimate,lower95,upper95)
```

###2.2 Local linear ï¬t without assuming continuity at the knots
Local linear ï¬t without assuming continuity at the knots for Î²0(t), b0i(t), Î²1(t) and b1i(t), i.e., using the basis functions as in #1.2; 

Model:
$$ Y_{ij} =\sum^6_{k=1}(Î²_k+b_{ki})B_kt_{kj}+\sum^{12}_{k=7}Î²_kB_{k-6}(t_{kj})S_{ij}+\epsilon_{ij} $$
```{r}
model.2.2<-lmer(CD4~-1+B1+B2+B3+B4+B5+B6+S1+S2+S3+S4+S5+S6+ (-1+B1+B2+B3+B4+B5+B6|ID), data= data2) 
summary(model.2.2)
```

Bootstrap

###2.3 Local linear ï¬t with continuity at the knots
Local linear ï¬t with continuity at the knots for Î²0(t), b0i(t), Î²1(t) and b1i(t), i.e., using the basis functions as in #1.3. 

Model:
$$ Y_{ij} =\sum^4_{k=1}(Î²_k+b_{ki})B_k(t_{kj})+\sum^{8}_{k=5}Î²_kB_{k-4}(t_{kj})S_{ij}+\epsilon_{ij} $$
Where
$$B_1(t)=1,B_2(t)= t,B_3(t)=(tâˆ’2)^+,B_4(t)=(tâˆ’4)^+ $$
```{r}
model.2.3<-lmer(CD4~b2+b3+b4+s1+s2+s3+s4+ (b2+b3+b4|ID), data= data2) 
summary(model.2.3)
```

Bootstrap

```{r}
set.seed(1)
bootstrap.2.3=sapply(1:200,function(o){
  b=bootsample()
  t=b$Time
  s=b$Smoke
  B2=function(t) return(t)
  B2=as.numeric(B2(t))
  B3=function(t) return(ifelse(t>2, t-2, 0))
  B3=as.numeric(B3(t))
  B4=function(t) return(ifelse(t>4, t-4, 0))
  B4=as.numeric(B4(t))
  S1=s
  S2=B2*s
  S3=B3*s
  S4=B4*s
  cd42.3<-cbind(b, B2,B3,B4,S1,S2,S3,S4)
  fit2.3<-lmer(CD4~B2+B3+B4+S1+S2+S3+S4+
                 (B2+B3+B4|ID), data= b)
  return(fixef(fit2.3))
})
bootstrap.2.3=as.matrix(bootstrap.2.3)
estimate=fixef(model.2.3)
upper95=apply(bootstrap.2.3,1,quantile,0.975)
lower95=apply(bootstrap.2.3,1,quantile,0.025)
cbind(estimate,lower95,upper95)
```

###2.4 Interpretations and clinical conclusions
What are your interpretations and clinical conclusions about the eï¬€ects of smoking status obtained in #2.1, #2.2 and #2.3?

```{r}
anova(model.2.1,model.2.2,model.2.3,refit=F)
```

Model.2.2 is the best one because it has the smallest AIC.
We can see from the model that smokers' post-CD4 level decreaseS faster then non-smokers in all time interval. The relationship between post-CD4 cell level and time is the same as the conclusion in 1.4.
